results.snippet: PROSPECT PARK  Carp, Bass and Catfish To Test Children's Skills      Some 1,400 young anglers from around the city will test their fish-catching skills on Friday, Saturday and next week at the annual fishing contest at Prospect Park Lake near  the...
results.lead_paragraph: PROSPECT PARK Carp, Bass and Catfish To Test Children's Skills Some 1,400 young anglers from around the city will test their fish-catching skills on Friday, Saturday and next week at the annual fishing contest at Prospect Park Lake near the Kate Wollman Ice Skating Rink in Prospect Park.

results.abstract: Science Museum of Long Island president John T Tanacredi letter questions why museum was referred to as 'pocket museum' in June 20 article on plan to build new science and technology museum on Long Island (M)
results.snippet: We were quite amused and perplexed to see the Science Museum of Long Island referred to as a ''pocket museum'' in the June 20 article, ''Inventing a Science and Technology Museum.'' Over the years, the museum has attracted luminaries such as the...
results.section_name: Technology; Science; New York and Region; Opinion
results.lead_paragraph: We were quite amused and perplexed to see the Science Museum of Long Island referred to as a ''pocket museum'' in the June 20 article, ''Inventing a Science and Technology Museum.'' Over the years, the museum has attracted luminaries such as the Nobel Prize winner Frank Oppenheimer, the astronaut Scott Carpenter, the Russian cosmonaut Viktor Savinhykh, the oceanographer Sylvia Earle, the environmentalist Jim Fowler and the Antarctic specialist Rita Mathews. These and other top scientists have visited the museum and contributed to our courses, workshops and lectures because they felt our hands-on science programs for children were substantive and dynamic. Our director, Dr. John Loret, is a marine biologist who has participated in expeditions with Thor Heyerdahl. Dr. Loret, a former Explorer's Club president, has led more than 35 global science expeditions himself. You don't draw a stellar caliber of people like the ones mentioned to collaborate with or direct an organization when you're merely a ''pocket museum.'' Last year alone, more than 92,000 schoolchildren and adults participated in the museums programs and activities. Our courses run the gamut in variety. In our paleontology program, students actually unearth bones, map them out, then create protective jackets around them just as paleontologists do, or they may build an advanced rocket and launch it in our rocketry program. Others might collect and maintain live specimens from the sea and perform salinity experiments on a boat that goes out in the Long Island Sound. As for our widely popular travel expeditions for adults, CNN filmed our 1998 trip to Easter Island because of the El Nino implications in the Pacific Ocean that we investigated. The program, ''Forging Ahead: Easter Island Expedition,'' aired several times nationally and itnernationally last fall. The History Channel also aired the program this June.

results.abstract: Pete Conrad, who flew four space missions and was third man to walk on Moon, dies after motorcycle accident in California, at age 69; photos (M)

headline.main: Pete Conrad, 69, the Third Man to Walk on the Moon, Dies After a Motorcycle Crash

results.snippet: Pete Conrad, who flew to the Moon nearly 30 years ago and became the third man to walk upon it, died Thursday evening after crashing his motorcycle near Ojai, Calif.    The former astronaut and Navy captain, who had survived more than 1,100 hours of...
results.lead_paragraph: Pete Conrad, who flew to the Moon nearly 30 years ago and became the third man to walk upon it, died Thursday evening after crashing his motorcycle near Ojai, Calif. The former astronaut and Navy captain, who had survived more than 1,100 hours of often perilous space exploration, was 69.

results.abstract: Space artifacts on exhibit at Oregon Museum of Science and Industry noted; photo (S)

headline.main: Portland Museum Show Gathers Space Artifacts

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: OREGON MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY

results.snippet: ''Imagine Space!,'' a collection of space artifacts, is on view through Sept. 6 at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry in Portland.    Displays include a jumpsuit worn during the Apollo 16 mission to the moon, a Russian spacesuit and a number...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Imagine Space!,'' a collection of space artifacts, is on view through Sept. 6 at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry in Portland. Displays include a jumpsuit worn during the Apollo 16 mission to the moon, a Russian spacesuit and a number of moon rocks. There is also a 17-foot model of the Space Shuttle Columbia, a full-scale model of the Mercury capsule flown by John Glenn in 1961 and samples of the food eaten in space by astronauts. Interactive exhibits allow visitors to take a spin on a Tri-Axis Astronaut Trainer Ride and to design, build and test model rovers, rockets and space stations.

results.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column notes that he drafted speech for Pres Richard Nixon in event there was mishap during Apollo XI moon landing 30 years ago, but mission, in which astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on moon, was success and speech never had to be given (M)
results.snippet: ''Fate has ordained,'' a saddened President was prepared to say, ''that the men who went to the moon to explore in peace will stay to rest in peace.''    That was the opening line of a speech to the nation that I drafted for Richard Nixon 30 years...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Fate has ordained,'' a saddened President was prepared to say, ''that the men who went to the moon to explore in peace will stay to rest in peace.'' That was the opening line of a speech to the nation that I drafted for Richard Nixon 30 years ago this week, as Apollo XI was about to land on the moon.

results.abstract: Col Eileen M Collins of the Air Force will become first woman ever to command space shuttle on July 20, when she and four crew mates are to carry the Chandra X-ray Observatory into space aboard shuttle Columbia; Chandra, $2.7 billion giant, is to open large new window on cosmic extremes of violence and power, including exploding stars and baffling objects at the heart of galaxies; photo (L)

headline.main: Blasting Off on a Mission for Cosmic Science

results.snippet: The first woman ever to command a space shuttle, Col. Eileen M. Collins of the Air Force, is to take that step soon while hauling into orbit one of the largest and most costly science payloads of all time and then guiding her winged spaceship back to...
results.lead_paragraph: The first woman ever to command a space shuttle, Col. Eileen M. Collins of the Air Force, is to take that step soon while hauling into orbit one of the largest and most costly science payloads of all time and then guiding her winged spaceship back to Earth for a tricky night landing. A week from today, on July 20, Colonel Collins and four crew mates on the shuttle Columbia are to carry into space the Chandra X-ray Observatory.

results.abstract: International space experts say that China could be able to launch humans into space as early as next year; say officials had hoped to put two astronauts into space by October to celebrate 50th anniversary of Communist takeover of China, but were set back by delays in developing new rocket for lifting heavy payloads and problems with other equipment; say an unmanned test of the new rocket and spacecraft could still come in October; photo (M)

headline.main: China's Bid To Send Astronauts Into Space

results.snippet: China is closer to becoming only the third nation in history to launch humans into space, a feat that could come as early as next year, say international space experts.    After years of saying it would ''one day'' or ''soon'' put people into space,...
results.lead_paragraph: China is closer to becoming only the third nation in history to launch humans into space, a feat that could come as early as next year, say international space experts. After years of saying it would ''one day'' or ''soon'' put people into space, and initiating and postponing efforts to do so, the Chinese government has finally embarked on a serious program to make it happen, these experts believe.

results.abstract: J C Herz Game Theory column on Ultima computer game series, created by Richard Garriott; Ascension, ninth and final chapter of the saga, is to be released in autumn ; photo (M)

headline.main: A Designer's Farewell to His Fantasy Realm

results.snippet: GEORGE LUCAS isn't the only auteur who's been working on the same fictional universe for 20 years. In the lesser-known realm of computer games, Richard Garriott is the artistic marathon runner whose creations have sustained generations of rabid fans...
results.lead_paragraph: GEORGE LUCAS isn't the only auteur who's been working on the same fictional universe for 20 years. In the lesser-known realm of computer games, Richard Garriott is the artistic marathon runner whose creations have sustained generations of rabid fans over the decades. As the creator of Ultima, the longest-running fiction in digital media, Mr. Garriott has tended his vision from the dawn of the PC era to the wired world of sprawling multiplayer on-line games. Like the Star Wars trilogy, Mr. Garriott's computer games have evolved technologically. When Ascension, the ninth and final chapter in the Ultima saga, arrives this autumn, Ultima's fictional realm of Brittannia will unfurl on computers that are 266 megahertz or more. But the underlying themes have always been compelling enough to make the story viable, even when computer speeds were in the low double digits.

results.abstract: Children will be in Central Park's Sheep Meadow on July 17 to participate at Urban Park Rangers' Moon Day festivities to commemorate 30th anniversary of Apollo 11 moon landing; photo of Edwin E (Buzz) Aldrin Jr; comment on Tada's latest production, Golly Gee Whiz!, musical that captures high spirits of 1930's pop culture (M)
results.snippet: Many small steps will be taken across Central Park tomorrow evening, all in honor of a giant leap for mankind. Children will frolic on Sheep's Meadow at the Urban Park Rangers' Moon Day festivities, a celebration of all things lunar (and a few things...
results.lead_paragraph: Many small steps will be taken across Central Park tomorrow evening, all in honor of a giant leap for mankind. Children will frolic on Sheep's Meadow at the Urban Park Rangers' Moon Day festivities, a celebration of all things lunar (and a few things Martian, too). ''We'll have a lot of interesting creatures, perhaps Martians, milling about,'' said Meredith Caccese, the Rangers' special events coordinator.

results.abstract: Crew of space shuttle Columbia arrives in Cape Canaveral, Fla, led by Col Eileen M Collins, who will be first woman to command space flight; photo (M)

headline.main: Woman Leads Shuttle Crew For History-Making Mission

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Columbia arrived here today, led by Col. Eileen M. Collins, slated to be the first woman to command a space flight when the shuttle blasts off on Tuesday.     Thirty years to the day after Apollo 11 left the Kennedy...
results.lead_paragraph: The crew of the space shuttle Columbia arrived here today, led by Col. Eileen M. Collins, slated to be the first woman to command a space flight when the shuttle blasts off on Tuesday. Thirty years to the day after Apollo 11 left the Kennedy Space Center for the Moon, Colonel Collins began her own historic mission with a ceremony known simply as crew arrival.

results.abstract: William J Cunningham 3d commentary, noting upcoming 30th anniversary of first lunar landing, salutes work of Jack English, Long Island lawyer who promoted Long Island's space manufacturing capabilities during Kennedy Administration (M)

headline.main: An Unsung Hero of the Space Age

results.snippet: MANY people will be remembered on Tuesday, the 30th anniversary of the first lunar landing. But as Long Island celebrates its role in building the Grumman lunar module that made the historic feat possible, we should also salute one crucial individual...
results.lead_paragraph: MANY people will be remembered on Tuesday, the 30th anniversary of the first lunar landing. But as Long Island celebrates its role in building the Grumman lunar module that made the historic feat possible, we should also salute one crucial individual in the effort who was neither engineer nor astronaut. Jack English was a politically savvy Long Island lawyer who was one of President John F. Kennedy's most trusted advisers. In an era that had not yet invented stealth technology, Jack used the political equivalent in promoting Long Island's space manufacturing capabilities so effectively but so quietly that today few people are aware of his efforts.

results.abstract: Profile of scene at PS 41 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, where teacher Shawn Hunt and her third-grade, 8- and 9-year-old students have just completed first two weeks of mandatory summer school, keystone of Chancellor Rudy Crew's program to end practice of of sending students on to the next grade whether they are ready or not; this year, in most ambitious and structured mandatory program since 1980's, 58,000 third, sixth and eighth graders are back in class for extra reading and writing, and to a lesser extent mathematics, to prepare them for promotion test in early August; photos (Article in series Catching Up: Summer at PS 41) (L)

headline.main: In Season of Play, Daunting Struggle to Learn

results.snippet: Outside, summer beckons, with bikes to be ridden, video games to be played, cartoons to be watched, Barbies to be pampered for hours on end.    But the third graders in a Brooklyn classroom must set those pleasures aside for now, ignore the teasing...
results.lead_paragraph: Outside, summer beckons, with bikes to be ridden, video games to be played, cartoons to be watched, Barbies to be pampered for hours on end. But the third graders in a Brooklyn classroom must set those pleasures aside for now, ignore the teasing afternoon breeze wafting through the windows and focus on the task at hand: to draw a picture based on one of three stories they have studied today and write a few sentences about why they liked it.

results.abstract: NASA officials, scientists and others involved in space projects prepare to celebrate 30th anniversary of Apollo 11 lunar landing even as they wonderabout space agency's fate; many worry that United States has lost can-do spirit and will to carry out ambitious, expensive space endeavors; some have mixed feelings about celebrations that dwell on the past; concern is that Apollo should not be held up as model for planning space exploration for long haul; project resulted from cold war confrontation between United States and Soviet Union; it was crash program and too expensive to be sustained once immediate goal was achieved; photo (M)

headline.main: Amid Apollo 11 Nostalgia, Questions on NASA's Fate

results.snippet: Over dinner a few weeks ago, a former astronaut who walked on the Moon and one of the Apollo flight directors got to skylarking about the good old days, something people do when they think of their past receding and a big anniversary approaching, in...
results.lead_paragraph: Over dinner a few weeks ago, a former astronaut who walked on the Moon and one of the Apollo flight directors got to skylarking about the good old days, something people do when they think of their past receding and a big anniversary approaching, in this case the 30th anniversary of the Apollo 11 lunar landing on July 20, 1969. They laughed almost to tears telling cherished stories, one trying to top the other, about the time men flew to the Moon.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students gain an understanding of the significance of the Apollo 11 lunar landing thirty years later by interviewing an adult about his or her memories of the specific events and impact of the mission. Students then incorporate their interviews into news articles, imagining that they are journalists in July 1969 with the goal of documenting citizens' views of this historic 'step for mankind.'
results.snippet: In this lesson, students gain an understanding of the significance of the Apollo 11 lunar landing thirty years later by interviewing an adult about his or her memories of the specific events and impact of the mission. Students then incorporate their...

results.abstract: Students examine the Apollo lunar landings and past theories about the creation and structure of the Earth's Moon as a springboard for investigating missions and milestones in space exploration since the creation of NASA in 1958.

headline.main: 2 Leaders: To Speed the Peace Effort

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference yesterday in the Old Executive Office Building by President Clinton and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, as recorded by The New York Times.    PRESIDENT CLINTON -- Prime Minister Barak...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference yesterday in the Old Executive Office Building by President Clinton and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, as recorded by The New York Times. PRESIDENT CLINTON -- Prime Minister Barak and I have had a very good series of meetings over the past few days. Of course we have focused primarily on the Middle East peace process. We strongly agree that a negotiated peace is the best way to make Israel more secure, the best path to lasting stability and prosperity for all the peoples of the Middle East. The Prime Minister is determined to accelerate that process, to reach, with Chairman Arafat, a permanent-status agreement between Israel and the Palestinian people and to achieve a broader regional peace that includes Syria and Lebanon. As he has said, the objective now is to put the peace process back on all its tracks.

headline.main: Kennedy Flight Ended in a Plunge, Radar Shows

results.snippet: The last flight of John F. Kennedy Jr. ended in a plunge at 10 times the normal rate for a descent, radar data released today showed, offering a possible explanation for searchers' failure to recover remains or significant pieces of wreckage from the...

byline.original: By MIKE ALLEN and CAREY GOLDBERG

results.lead_paragraph: The last flight of John F. Kennedy Jr. ended in a plunge at 10 times the normal rate for a descent, radar data released today showed, offering a possible explanation for searchers' failure to recover remains or significant pieces of wreckage from the crash. Aviation experts said that rate of descent before the crash on Friday night made it very likely that the plane was out of control, though it was uncertain whether it was because of equipment failure or pilot disorientation or other problems.
